sections.title: The Fame and Strength of Rome

verses.text: Judas had heard about the reputation of the Romans—how powerful they were, how they offered loyalty and friendship to those who joined with them, and how they made covenants with all who approached them.
verses.comment: The Romans' political alliances and their practice of binding treaties is highlighted here, establishing the context for the Jewish search for allies.
verses.sectionHeader: The Fame and Strength of Rome

verses.text: He had learned of their military campaigns and the heroic feats they accomplished against the Gauls—how they overcame them and imposed tribute on them.
verses.comment: This verse refers to the Roman conquests in Northern Italy/Gaul and their practice of subjugating defeated peoples.

verses.text: He also heard about their achievements in Spain, where they seized control of the rich silver and gold mines.
verses.comment: This passage probably refers to Rome's expansion into the Iberian Peninsula and their interest in its natural resources.

verses.text: Through skillful planning and patience, the Romans had managed to conquer territories far from their own. Even distant kings who rose up against them were defeated and severely punished, so that those who remained brought annual tribute.
verses.comment: This comments on Rome's administrative abilities and long-term strategies in managing their distant provinces.

verses.text: The Romans had triumphed in battle over Philip, Perseus the Macedonian king, and others who rose against them.
verses.comment: Historical reference to the Roman defeat of Macedonian kings during the Macedonian Wars.

verses.text: They also overcame Antiochus the Great, the king of Asia, who faced them with one hundred twenty elephants, a vast cavalry force, chariots, and an enormous army, yet was utterly routed by the Romans.
verses.comment: Antiochus III, also called the Great, was defeated by Rome at Magnesia in 190 BC.

verses.text: After capturing him alive, they forced him and his successors to pay a heavy tribute, surrender hostages, and cede some of his best provinces.
verses.comment: Rome imposed severe terms on Antiochus III after his defeat, including territorial losses and tribute.

verses.text: The Romans took the lands of India, Media, and Lydia from him and entrusted them to King Eumenes.
verses.comment: This refers to the redistribution of the Seleucid territories to Rome's ally, Eumenes II of Pergamum.

verses.text: The Greeks had plotted to come and wipe out the Romans,
verses.comment: This summarizes a Greek coalition's failed attempt to challenge Roman supremacy.

verses.text: but the Romans learned of their plan, dispatched a general, went to war against them, inflicted heavy casualties, took their wives and children captive, pillaged them, seized their land, demolished their forts, and enslaved them, where they remain to this day.
verses.comment: Rome's crushing of Greek opposition and enslavement of Greek peoples is noted here.

verses.text: In fact, any kingdom or island that stood against them, they utterly destroyed and subjugated.
verses.comment: The scope of Roman expansion and their tendency to utterly subdue opponents is emphasized.

verses.text: but with their friends and those who rely on them they have kept friendship. They have subdued kings far and near, and as many as have heard of their fame have feared them.
verses.comment: Highlights Roman loyalty toward allies, contrasting with their dominance over kings near and far; emphasizes their reputation and reliability.

verses.text: Those whom they wish to help and to make kings, they make kings, and those whom they wish they depose; and they have been greatly exalted.
verses.comment: Stresses the Romans' unique authority to appoint or depose rulers, and their resulting exaltation among nations.

verses.text: Yet for all this not one of them has put on a crown or worn purple as a mark of pride,
verses.comment: Specifies that no Roman has adopted royal insignia or purple as a display of pride; emphasizes Roman republican modesty versus monarchy.

verses.text: Instead, they built a senate, where three hundred twenty senators meet daily to deliberate continually about the concerns of the people, ensuring just governance.
verses.comment: This describes the Roman Senate's unique role in government, presented as a model of republican governance.

verses.text: They trust one man each year to rule over them and to control all their land; they all heed the one man, and there is no envy or jealousy among them.
verses.comment: Describes the annual election of a chief magistrate, the singular obedience he commands, and the absence of envy—stressing Roman political order.

verses.text: Judas then selected Eupolemus, son of John son of Accos, and Jason, son of Eleazar, and sent them to Rome to establish a partnership and treaty of friendship,
verses.comment: Jewish envoys are chosen by Judas to negotiate with Rome, marking a significant diplomatic milestone.

verses.text: and to free themselves from the yoke; for they saw that the kingdom of the Greeks was enslaving Israel completely.
verses.comment: Notes that the Jewish embassy to Rome was motivated by a desire for liberation from oppressive Greek/Seleucid rule.

verses.text: They journeyed a great distance to Rome, and upon arrival, entered the senate and spoke as follows:
verses.comment: Describes the delegation’s long journey and the formality of their approach to Rome’s governing body.

verses.text: "Judas, who is also called Maccabeus, and his brothers and the Jewish people have sent us to forge an alliance and peace with you, that we may be counted among your allies and friends."
verses.comment: The formal wording of the Jewish request echoes international treaty language.

verses.text: Their proposal was well received by the Romans.
verses.comment: The positive response paves the way for a treaty between the two peoples.

verses.text: This is a copy of the letter they wrote in reply, which they engraved on bronze tablets and sent to Jerusalem as a lasting record of their alliance and peace:
verses.comment: Bronze tablets were standard for binding and enduring Roman treaties.

verses.text: “May all go well with the Romans and with the nation of the Jews at sea and on land forever, and may sword and enemy be far from them.
verses.comment: The formal greeting and blessing at the start of the treaty, praying for perpetual peace, prosperity, and safety for both nations.

verses.text: If Rome or any of their allies in any district faces war first,
verses.comment: The treaty stipulates mutual defense if Rome or its allies are attacked.

verses.text: then the Jewish nation shall support them as devoted allies, as circumstances require.
verses.comment: The wording reflects loyalty and the willingness to respond as situations demand.

verses.text: To the enemy that makes war they shall not give or supply grain, arms, money, or ships, just as Rome has decided; and they shall keep their obligations without receiving any return.
verses.comment: Stipulates that neither side will provide material aid to their adversaries; reinforces mutual obligation without expectation of reward.

verses.text: In the same way, if war comes first to the nation of the Jews, the Romans shall willingly act as their allies, as the occasion may indicate to them.
verses.comment: Ensures reciprocal military aid from Rome should Judea be attacked, according to Roman discretion.

verses.text: And to their enemies there shall not be given grain, arms, money, or ships, just as Rome has decided; and they shall keep these obligations and do so without deceit.
verses.comment: Restates the absolute refusal of aid to enemies, the requirement for loyalty, and that these obligations are to be fulfilled honestly.

verses.text: Thus on these terms the Romans make a treaty with the Jewish people.
verses.comment: Confirms the binding nature of the treaty ratified on the stated conditions.

verses.text: If in the future both parties agree to add or remove anything from these terms, they may do so as they see fit, and whatever they decide will stand.
verses.comment: The treaty is amenable to changes by mutual consent.

verses.text: "As for the injustices King Demetrius has done to them, we have written to him: 'Why are you burdening our friends and allies, the Jews, with your yoke?'"
verses.comment: Mentions Roman diplomatic intervention on behalf of the Jews regarding Seleucid oppression.

verses.text: If they call on us again for help against you, we will uphold their rights and fight you on land and sea."
verses.comment: Concludes the treaty with a stern warning to Demetrius and a promise to defend their new ally, Judea.
